rationale: The triple can be inferred from the given information using the rdfs:domain property of ex:r2, which implies that any subject of ex:r2 (in this case, ex:x1) must be of type ex:t1.

The owl:sameAs predicate expresses identity, and any entity is always identical to itself. The triple <http://example.org/y1> owl:sameAs <http://example.org/y1> is a statement of self-identity, which is always true regardless of any other information in the knowledge base.
The triple is true because ex:y1 is the object of a triple with predicate ex:r2, and ex:r2 has a range of ex:t2. According to RDF semantics, this implies that ex:y1 must be of type ex:t2.
The owl:sameAs predicate expresses identity, and any entity is always identical to itself. This is a fundamental logical principle that holds regardless of any other contextual information.

The functional property ex:r2 relates ex:x1 to both ex:y1 and ex:y2. Since a functional property can only relate a subject to one unique object, this implies that ex:y1 and ex:y2 must be the same entity. Therefore, the statement ex:y2 owl:sameAs ex:y1 is true.

The owl:sameAs predicate is reflexive, meaning that any entity is always the same as itself. Since both the subject and object of the triple are identical (<http://example.org/x1>), this triple is true by definition, regardless of any other information provided about x1.

Given that ex:r2 is a functional property and ex:x1 has both ex:y1 and ex:y2 as values for this property, we can conclude that ex:y1 and ex:y2 must refer to the same entity. This is exactly what the owl:sameAs predicate expresses.
The triple is true because y2 is the object of relation r2, and r2 has a range of t2. According to RDFS semantics, this implies that y2 is of type t2.
